awd_titl_txt: Understanding the Dynamics of El Nino-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) Complexity
awd_abstract_narration:
El Nino/Southern Oscillation (ENSO) events occur when sea surface temperature (SST) warms (El Nino) or cools (La Nina) along the equator in the central and eastern Pacific (CP and EP, respectively). These events have worldwide consequences from disruptions in tropical monsoons to changes in the severity of winter weather over the United States and Canada.  The interplay of ocean currents, surface winds, and precipitation leading to ENSO events has been intensively studied, and the underlying dynamical mechanisms have been identified. But important questions remain, particularly regarding event-to-event differences in ENSO behavior that compromise prediction efforts. The term "ENSO complexity" has been coined to refer to differences commonly observed between individual events.  Past work on the topic has emphasized differences in the SST pattern at the peak of the ENSO event, in particular the location of the maximum SST anomaly in either the CP or EP.  Work here complements this analysis by looking at systematic differences in event transition, seeking  to explain why some warm events are immediately followed by cold events and vice versa while others, particularly cold events, linger for multiple years.

Preliminary research by the Principal Investigator (PI) identifies distinct onset mechanisms for ENSO oscillation between warm and cold events and for persistent events of the same sign.  In the charge-discharge (CD) mechanism, warm water accumulates in the upper ocean over the equatorial Pacific prior to the onset of a warm event and is subsequently discharged to higher latitudes.  This mechanism leads to oscillations in which warm events are followed directly by cold events. In the seasonal footprinting (SF) mechanism, wintertime weather anomalies in the middle latitudes cause ocean temperature changes which in turn produce changes in the surface winds.  The surface wind changes propagate into the tropical Pacific and result in ENSO events, and the PI's work links this mechanism to multi-year cold events.  Further work suggests that changes in ENSO behavior since 1980 are associated with enhancement of the SF mechanism, and that climate models overrepresent the CD mechanism and thus produce ENSO events which are too regular.

This project will address five related goals: 1) understanding the combined effects on ENSO complexity of the CD and SF onset mechanisms and subsequent ENSO evolution; 2) understanding the cause of the asymmetry between the positive and negative phases of the SF mechanism; 3) understanding the mean state sensitivity and slow variations in the CD and SF mechanisms; 4) using ENSO complexity dynamics to understand future ENSO projections and to develop new metrics for model intercomparisons; and 5) using ENSO complexity dynamics to understand ENSO activity in paleoclimate datasets.  The work is performed through analysis of observational datasets and simulations using climate models in a variety of configurations. Work addressing goal 5 uses data from the Last Millennium Reanalysis to examine differences in ENSO complexity between the Medieval Climate Anomaly of the period 950 to 1250 and the Little Ice Age period (1300 to 1850).

This research has societal relevance due to the worldwide impacts of ENSO events and the desirability of skillful forecasts of them to allow for appropriate preparations.  The work is directly relevant to forecasting given the focus on warm-to-cold transition versus multi-year persistence, a central challenge of ENSO prediction.  The finding that the SF mechanism has become more prominent in recent decades also has implications for anticipating future changes in ENSO behavior.   The project would support and train a postdoctoral researcher as well as a graduate student and a graduate student, thus providing for the future workforce in this research area.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Atmospheric and Geospace Sciences

por.por_cntn:
1. Project Goals
The noticeable changes in ENSO properties during recent decades have prompted the research community to understand the causes of ENSO complexity. We hypothesized that ENSO transition complexity is controlled by the onset mechanism of ENSO, which includes the charged-discharged and seasonal footprinting mechanisms. The former operates within the tropical Pacific (TP) and is referred to as the TP ENSO dynamics, while the latter triggers ENSO events from the subtropical Pacific (SP) and is referred to as the SP ENSO dynamics. The goals of this project include: (1) to understand the contributions of the TP and SP ENSO dynamics to ENSO complexity; (2) to understand the contributions of these dynamics to El Nino-La Nina asymmetries; (3) to evaluate the representations of ENSO complexity and its dynamics in climate models; and (4) to understand ENSO complexity in past and future climates. 

 

2. Outcomes in understanding and quantifying the individual contributions of the TP and SP ENSO dynamics to ENSO complexity
This project identified the SP ENSO dynamics, inter-basin interactions, the Australian monsoon, the 11-year solar cycle, and Maritime Continent (MC) deforestation as five possible factors  producing complexity in ENSO's spatial pattern and temporal evolution. Figure 1 summarizes these major factors in ENSO complexity dynamics. Process (1) indicates the TP ENSO dynamics tends to produce the Eastern Pacific (EP) ENSO, while the SP ENSO dynamics produces the Central Pacific (CP) type. Process (2) indicates that the EP ENSOs tend to be single-year events. Process (3) indicates that CP ENSOs tend to be multi-year events due to their ability to turn on the SP ENSO dynamics . Process (4) indicates that inter-basin interactions can also affect ENSO complexity. Process (5) indicates that the Australian monsoon variations can affect ENSO complexity via surface wind anomalies over the far western Pacific. Process (6) indicates that MC deforestation plays a role in causing ENSO complexity. Process (7) indicates that the 11-year solar cycle can induce a sea surface temperature footprint over the northeastern Pacific to affect ENSO complexity by modulating the strength of the SP ENSO dynamics.

 

3. Outcomes in understanding the contributions of the TP and SP ENSO dynamics to El Nino-La Nina asymmetries
It is well known that El Ninos tend to be single-year events, while La Ninas tend to be multi-year events. This project finds that this asymmetry can be easily explained by the SP ENSO dynamics but not by the TP ENSO dynamics. The SP ENSO dynamics responds differently to the El Nino and La Nina phases and this is a key reason for the observed El Nino-La Nina asymmetry. Figure 2 explains the reason why the SP ENSO dynamics responds differently to El Nino and La Nina. Figure 2a indicates that sea surface temperature (SST) anomalies (color shading) in the equatorial central Pacific (ECP) or equatorial eastern Pacific (EEP) can excite the surface wind anomalies (vectors) associated with the subtropical Pacific ENSO dynamics via a Gill-type response (brown arrows) and Rossby wave train in the lower troposphere (blue solid and dashed arrows) and the associated descending motions (large blue arrow). However, Figure 2b shows that the ECP background SSTs just pass the threshold (horizontal thin-solid lines). La Nian events there can induce a large anomalous cooling to activate the SP ENSO dynamics, while El Nino events cannot induce large anomalous warming to activate the SP ENSO dynamics. 

 

4. Outcomes in evaluating the representations of these key coupling processes and the resulting ENSO complexity in contemporary climate models
Climate models have been used to project how ENSO complexity may change in the future as the world warms. It is necessary to examine whether or not contemporary models can realistically simulate the ENSO complexity dynamics and contemporary ENSO complexity. This project finds that the CMIP5 models fail to simulate the El Nino-La Nina asymmetry in their evolution patterns due to a model cold bias in their tropical mean states and their overly weak subtropical ENSO dynamics. Using CMIP5 and CMIP6 future projections, this project finds that multi-year ENSO events are projected to decrease and cyclic ENSO events to increase as the climate warms. An effort was also made to develop a simple conceptual model for the ENSO complexity dynamics.

5. Broader impacts from the outcomes 
The SP ENSO dynamics developed as part of this project can better explain why more Central Pacific and multi-year El Nino and La Nina events have occurred so far in the twenty-first century. The understanding obtained from this project have the potential to lead to improvements in predicting the more complex and less-predictable ENSO events in the 21st century. The understanding obtained can also help in developing new ways to interpret paleoclimate proxies of Earth's past climate. Finally, the project trained graduate students, post-doctoral researchers, and undergraduate students in the rapidly growing Earth System Science Department at University of California, Irvine.


Last Modified: 12/20/2022
Modified by: Jin-Yi Yu

    The Framework of ENSO Complexity Dynamics
  • Figure 2. An illustration to explain the reason why the SP ENSO dynamics responds differently to El Nino and La Nina. This difference is closely related to the present-day background SSTs in the tropical central Pacific. See the Outcome Report for details.
    https://doi.org/10.1029/2020GL087933
    Copyrighted
    Jin-Yi Yu
    Causes of El Nino-La Nina Asymmetries in ENSO Complexity
